title: Which data type can hold a 32-bit signed integer? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends on the programming language and on the specific implementation of the language. For example: If you’re talking about C or C++, the int data type might be 16-bit, 32-bit, 64-bit, or more, varying from one compiler implementation to another. A long or long int might be 32 bits, 64 bits, or more. Even a short or short int might be 32 bits in some implementations.But the fixed width integer type int32_t, defined in stdint.h in C and cstdint in C++, is guaranteed to occupy 32 bits.If you’re talking about C#, the int keyword is a shorthand for the struct System.Int32, which is guaranteed to occupy 32 bits.If you’re talking about Java, int is always 32 bits.In some environments, including various assembly languages, a word data type might be 16 bits, 32 bits, or 64 bits. A doubleword (DWORD) might be 32 bits or 64 bits.There are many programming languages, and many possible data types in which a 32-bit signed integer data type might be specified. In some cases, just specifying the programming language only tells part of the story. In some cases, you also need to choose a specific implementation of the language to pin down which signed integer data types occupy 32 bits.

In C, the language defines “int32_t” in the header file stdint.h. On most 32 bit and 64 bit platforms these days, “int” is also 32 bits which you can check via sizeof(int) == sizeof(int32_t). On C for microcontrollers, int is likely to be 16 bits, but int32_t should still be 32 bits.
In what programming language? You failed to specify the language and the type names are different from language to language.
